story:
I have been invited to create another eX Marks The Spot HeArt Attack for the February edition of The News at SOMArts hosted by Peter Max Lawrence. The HeArt Attack will be a 6 foot tall paper mache pinata filled with candy that will be broken with a bedpost as the finale of a larger performance about broken relationships. This years 2013 HeArt Attack will take on a more Victorian paper cut feel with lots of decoupage roses. Since this years HeArt will not be accompanied by a game of bingo as it was in 2006, it will be filled with relics from my more recent relationship history & be broken at the end of The News on 5 February 2013.

I am offering smaller HeArt Attack Piñatas for sale here on Indiegog along with some other relics related to my most recent heartbreaks to raise funds for materials & travel expenses back to San Francisco for the February Event. By contributing to eX Marks The Spot, not only are you going to get a little piece of my heart, you will be contributing to an emerging body of my work that is rooted in capturing moments of our collective emotions in beautiful art objects. Thanks for all those broken hearts everyone! Lets make some Art & break some more…

Most of the relics I have left from the 2006 Performance are being shipped off to be part of the permanent collection in the Museum of Broken Relationships that is on tour now and will open in Boulder, Colorodo on Valentines Day at the Boulder Museum of Contemporary Art in 2013.

My 2006 Performance of eX Marks the Spot was part of group show of Interactive Art hosted by Red Ink Studios in San Francisco, CA. Features included painful & hysterical accounts of all of my major heartbreaks to date through the recreation of a Mexican Style game of Bingo. The backdrop for my Performance of Broken Heart Bingo was a massive plastic shrine constructed with plastic, fake roses and piles of Mardi Gras beads. The shrine set the stage perfectly for the interactive game of Mexican bingo that I hosted with a revolving roster of the 300+ participants that attended the show.

The game featured handmade bingo cards & an oversized game spinner that hosted drawings that represented my most devastating relationships. Door prizes were offered but frequently rejected as they included bouquets of abandoned tooth brushes, expired condoms, half eaten lunches, old journals, printed versions of horrible emails, mix CD’s of break up songs, parking violations and abandoned porno videos.

Posters for eX Marks the Spot were plastered around San Francisco and passed out as folded heart shaped notes as invitations. At the end of the entire event hosted by Red Ink Studios, the 5.5ft tall anatomically correct heart paper mache piñata was destroyed. Several guests at the event volunteered to break my HeART with a bedpost. Suspended from a beam 30ft overhead, the wireframe piñata was filled with Circus Peanuts & covered with cut tissue paper, glitter and finished with 200+ fake roses as the veins.

LaRece Egli grew up in a remote village Naknek, Alaska. Her experiences there have become the foundation of her life & work as a Survivalist Artist & Extreme Homemaker at her seasonal residence in Bellevue, Idaho. Her work emphases the emotional threads that connect all of us by recreating interactions with everyday objects. This focus has generated two successful businesses, LaRece Construction & Vago HTS. She has also launched multiple Performance Art campaigns including Twice The Guilt & eX Marks The Spot and is currently planning two new Performance pieces, Counter Culture which is based on the history of Home Economics & The Strait Story which is a series of functional strait jackets constructed from significant pieces of fabric from her life.

Follow the project on

Indiegogo indiegogo.com/eXMarksTheSpot/x/1870899

Facebook facebook.com/BrokenHeartBingo

Twitter twitter.com/eXMarksTheSpot2

Blogspot lessislamore.blogspot.com/

Related links

http://www.somarts.org/

http://brokenships.com/

Other links

http://www.facebook.com/LaReceConstruction

http://www.facebook.com/VagoHardwareTransportSystems

story:
**This campaign was setup for people who missed out on my Kickstarter campaign which I needed to raise $3000 to sell my collection of prints. This project was extremely popular and finished at 218% funded!. We are now pre-selling the FULL set of 5 prints with the 6th bonus print FREE!**


My name is Andrew Oatham. I’m a Visual Artist living in Melbourne, Australia. I was born in  England, where I started my art and design career, and I have always been fascinated with the often outlandish and disturbing medical and historic etchings, and the drawings from our past. I always wanted to own modern artistic representations of this genre for my walls. After consulting with a client in my gallery I put forward my artistic concepts and vision, and was instantly commissioned to create a limited edition print in this style - my artwork ’Stolen’ was born. From that vision I further developed the style to create other open edition versions.

I’m using crowd funding to release my new artworks sets to an international audience which have previously only been available as framed artwork, and I need your support to reach my goal. 

*All art prints will be individually printed, hand-signed, sealed, and posted, personally by Andrew Oatham.

I am looking forward to this being the first of many new artworks available as art prints, as well as framed artwork, in multiple sizes distributed globally. Art prints are professional High-End, Gallery Quality, Acid-Free Archival Paper Giclee prints, printed with UltraChrome® HDR all-pigment aqueous inks. as well as some more budget-conscious, quality smaller versions printed with high resolution Epson UltraChrome® K3 inks on Acid-Free Archival Paper.

Immortalising the past and repurposing it for the future, each artwork contains historic images taken from vintage medical books which have fallen into the public domain, these are reborn in Photoshop and Illustrator and vectorised so the highest possible print resolution can be achieved. Parts of elements are redrawn, new elements are created and some elements are pulled from our vintage vector library, and then layered to give the perfect visual balance. Each artwork has literally hundreds of separate layers!

Finally, each artwork is put through multiple print tests and 'tweaks' to check colours, and layout before the image is locked down and made print-ready for art lovers everywhere.

Art prints are professional High-End, Gallery Quality, Acid-Free Archival Paper Giclee prints, printed with UltraChrome® HDR all-pigment aqueous inks. as well as some more budget-conscious, quality smaller versions printed with high resolution Epson UltraChrome® K3 inks on Acid-Free Archival Paper.






**BONUS PRINT. FREE WITH ALL SETS OF 5 PRINTS**


Each print measures 5x7 (178mm by 127mm) approx.



Each print measures A4 (297mm by 210mm) approx.

Each print measures 17 inches at its shortest point (555mm by 432mm) approx.




As I have already successfully delivered this project on Kickstarter on time, I have learned everything I need to know about creating and posting a high number of these prints on time.


If you want to know more about me or my work, please head over to my website @ www.AndrewOatham.com.au

story:
Hi there, hunty!

Thanks for checking out my crowd-funding campaign! My name is CeCe Nicole Pearson and I am on a mission to raise money for the LeioMyoSarcoma Foundation. I know I said that the monies collected would go to one person, and they will, but let me explain. (I would make a video, but I am just too computer illiterate (especially when your computer is a fossil) So let's start at the beginning.

Once upon a time I was a happy kid, going to school, not trying at school, giving my mother a plethora of gray hairs....but one day my mom (I am adopted) was diagnosed with a rare cancer that I could hardly spell -- until now -- called LeioMyoSarcoma. Which is one of the rarest and least understood types of sarcoma. She passed away on February 15, 2013, after a year of battling that relentless b*ch.

Some of my mom's tissue was sent to a lab in the upper Northwest to help study this cancer. But they need more. More tissue, and more money to transport other donors tissue to the labs, they need more donations to continue the good work that they do. They hope, and I hope, to find a cure for this relentless killer that took my mom away from me and my family.

So here's the deal.

As a drag queen, okay I haven't officially started yet, because after my mom's death a lot of things got put on hold. Even after working all this time and trying to save money to do all this amazing service for the LMSF, I just haven't been able to.

So again, here's the deal.

I'm looking to raise, (at least) $850.

Here's what it will be used for.

I'm trying to make a certain wardrobe for this benefit, and wardrobes for the queens that are going to help me raise money, I need to rent the space (that's where most of the money is going to go to.)

Here's the breakdown:

1. Venue for the Pink Ribbon Review: $450 for stage and bar rental

2. Equipment (drapes, tables, lights, staff): 150 (luckily I was able to get a discount on the quote for this and locked it in. :D 

2b. Equipment insurance: $50

3. Outfits for 3 queens and myself: $250


Then after that is all paid for we can go on with the CeCe's Pink Ribbon Review!
Where:

75% of all proceeds go to the LeiMyoSarcoma Foundation (25% is given as a donation to the Palm Bay Hospice team that helped ease my mothers suffering) 

Please help! This cause is near and dear to my heart.

Love,

CeCe Nicole Pearson, Esq.

****Receipts for all purchases (production and misc will be shown as a public confirmation)****

Outfits for 3 queens and myself: $250Then after that is all paid for we can go on with the CeCe's Pink Ribbon Review! Where: 75% of all proceeds go to the LeiMyoSarcoma Foundation (25% is given as a donation to the Palm Bay Hospice team that helped ease my mothers suffering) Please help! This cause is near and dear to my heart. Love, CeCe Nicole Pearson, Esq. ****Receipts for all purchases (production and misc will be shown as a public confirmation)****

story:
Hello! Thanks for taking the time to read this. (due to video problems the pitch will be delayed for a few days)

The ultra short summary? Two words.

Robot Skeletons.

The slightly longer version is robot skeletons of extinct animals cast from resin.That do stuff. What stuff exactly is up to you.

Resin because we won't damage anything of historical or paleontological value. 

As stated in our video (doh!), the initial goal is to put on what will be called an Extinction Event. This is an interactive art show and party where people can touch, operate, examine and interact with the skeletons of extinct species that may behave in an unexpected way. Hey, it's a resin cast skeleton of an extinct animal, did you think we would stop with just animating it?  Secondary and tertiary roles would be for non profit education outreach and broadening he pool of general knowledge. But mostly because it's neat. Who doesn't want to go to something like an Extinction Event?

Imagine a large warehouse space with music, drinks, and autonomous and semi autonomous creatures moving about. Sabertooth tigers, giant sloths, cave bears, wooly mammoth. Perhaps a small dino or two? Think interactive natural history museum with booze. We want people to feel free to touch and explore. All the things you never got to do as a kid in a more tradational enviroment.

Pretty much if it once lived on earth and we can reconstruct the skeletal system we can animate it.

But why stop there? Once it can be programmed, we can program it to do anything in reason just about. That's where you come in.  More on that in a minute.

There are many moving parts (no pun intended) to accomplishing this.

We need to either purchase or acquire permission to make molds of a number of different species. Some can be bought on the open market, which makes this even possible in the first place. For example a short faced bear is $19,000 for a cast. Hopefully we can work out a volume discount or learn to 3D print them or some combination.

Here is a vendor of such things as current and extinct species

http://theevolutionstore.com/store/extinct-animals-skeletons-bones

Then we need to secure the services of a full time or several part time robotics experts. Since it's such a large project we can only go so far with volunteers but we will go as far as we can. 

Next we need to purchase a vast array of motors, gears, wire, actuators, control systems, inputs, etc. whatever is needed to actually make each piece behave the way we want.

Naturally we need a place to put it all and work.

It's a tall order, but that's why we turned to you lovely crowdsourcers! With the power of the imagination and a kick ass idea things are possible now that never were before. This idea has been germinating for over 7 years and now is the time to make it a reality!

Now the extra good part; as a contributor not only will you get early access but we want your help in deciding what extra surprising behaviors our creations will exhibit. T-rex skull on wheels that is also a turntable? Roller skating sabertooth? Piano playing great cave bear? Articulated exoskeleton sloth skeleton? Help us out! Want to name one? Or pick an animal to resurrect? That is possible as well if raise enough.

Whatever we raise this will be going forward. A little and we will do a little one and try again. Some and we will do more and larger but it might take time. Enough and we are on a roll. Over goal and the skies the limit!

What say you, will you help make this crazy dream a reality?

story:
• I am a photographer and writer as well as a beach glass and copper sculptor living in Nova Scotia. The beauty of the rugged coastlines and the power of the ocean inspire me.

  • I choose to stay here in Nova Scotia. There aren't a lot of jobs, so I want to create my own.  I want to spend time with my growing boys. I would love to be able share my work with the world! I don't have enough funds to get started. I would really appreciate any help that some of you maybe able to provide, and it would help to fulfill my dreams of being a stay at home mom and be able to help support my boys with my photography, writing and wirework.
  • I was born 4 months early at a weight of 1 pound and 7 ounces. I spent the first three months of my life in Halifax at the IWK Childrens Hospital. My eyes were damaged but I survived. Part of why I love photography so much is that it helps me to be able to see things much clearer and up close.

I need business cards, brochures, prints, matts, sleeves and frames so I can participate in art shows, as well as attend markets and make my work more accessible to everyone.
  • If you donate $50 I will send you a signed 12 x 18 print. If you donate $20 I will send you a signed 5 x 7 print.
  • If i raise more than my goal I will put it towards photography equipment (I only have one lens). I would also put extra money raised towards learning more and improving my photography skills by attending photography workshops and classes.

Other Ways You Can Help:

I totally understand some people just can’t contribute, but that doesn’t mean you can’t help:

  • Get the word out and make some noise about my campaign.
  • Don't forget to use the Indiegogo share tools!


You can see more of my work on my facebook page. https://www.facebook.com/GoodNaturePhotographybyAngelFlanagan

story:
Kidzu Children’s Museum is an educational, interactive museum in Chapel Hill, North Carolina dedicated to inspiring children and the adults in their lives to learn through play. 

“The Sweet Life Illuminated", or ‘Spoondelier’ as local artist (and former Kidzu employee) Carter Hubbard calls it, is the signature centerpiece of Kidzu’s Makery, a creative art studio and maker space which invites visitors to tap into their creative energy and mix up real materials, tinker with real tools, and play with new ideas and processes.  The 10’ tall Spoondelier is adorned with more than 8,000 plastic spoons collected from Sugarland Bakery on East Franklin Street in Chapel Hill. The use of recycled and easily recognizable childhood objects embodies the very essence of Kidzu:  sustainably driven, creative to the core, and deeply community focused.  

This fund seeks to Save The Spoondelier, and make Kidzu it’s permanent home, as well as ensure that the Makery continues to reflect and celebrate the creativity of our region by featuring local artwork, hosting programs by local makers, and co-curating educational experiences that will inspire the next generation of 21st century learners.

The Makery set up for Kidzu's Launch Pad Grand Opening.  Photo by Chris Bitsas

What We Need & What You Get

We need your contribution to ensure that the Spoondellier continues to inspire children in our Makery.  Funds will go directly to purchasing this signature element and ensuring that the Makery continues to reflect and celebrate the creativity of our region by featuring local artwork, hosting STEAM (science, technology, engineering, arts and math) programs by local makers, and bringing in new technologies to share with our community.

The Impact

“Creativity now is as important in education as literacy, and we should treat it with the same status. We don’t grow into creativity, we grow out of it. We’re being educated out of it.”   --Sir Ken Robinson

"Maker Education" has become one of the fastest growing trends in the informal learning field.  The Maker Movement began in 2005, when Make Magazine was published by Dale Dougherty.  However, the roots of making go as far back as recorded history.  What is particularly novel about making in the last decade is the creative mix it represents of such fields as crafting, design, and technology. Making fosters "experimental play" and a "resurgence of the do-it-yourself (DIY) movement" intersecting with technology, science, engineering, math, the arts and a host of other disciplines.  Making is the ultimate cross-disciplinary approach to learning. 

Kidzu visitors enjoy a sewing workshop with Jen Gilcrest, visiting fabric artist

The Makery was designed to counteract the alarming decrease in creativity among children that has been documented by researchers in the United States.  It is a creative, STEAM'D (science, technology, engineering, art, math and design) laboratory where children and families can tinker, invent and create to their hearts' content.  The 10' Spoondelier hangs boldly at its center, continuing Kidzu's tradition of sharing the exceptional creative capital of the Research Triangle area.  The Spoondelier weaves together color and form, beauty and whimsy, and encourages children and adults to think about sustainability in creative ways.  

In addition to showcasing local artwork, The Makery brings local artists and makers from a variety of fields to share their creative expertise with the families of our community.  Free demonstrations and more in-depth workshops nurture children's creativity, motivating them - and their accompanying adults - to create for the joy of the experience and to recognize the inherent creative potential of all people, big or small. 

Creative professionals also aid in teaching Kidzu staff new technologies and techniques to ensure that the Makery stays current and fresh.  In turn, we have seen that these creative professionals are inspired by the creativity of our young audience, receiving fresh ideas and energy to shape their work and creative outlook.  This fund, in addition to other grant funding, will offset some of the cost of hosting Kidzu's "community-in-residence."


The Spoondelier has quickly become a beloved and iconic element of Kidzu's Makery. 

Photo by Chris Bitsas

The Sweet Life Illuminated (Spoondelier) - Carter Hubbard, Carrboro, NC

Local artist Carter Hubbard uses recycled materials to create her art.  She collected nearly 38,000 spoons over one year and used over 8,000 of them to create her 10 foot Spoondelier, which took over 200 hours to make and won the People’s Choice Award in the Scrapple Hill II Exhibition held at University Mall in 2010.  The spoons only came in 3 colors, pink, blue and yellow, but the artist overlapped the primaries to create 3 additional colors: orange, purple and green.

story:
Artists John Shimon and Julie Lindemann designed the Harvestore Bandshell as both an homage to Wisconsin’s agricultural history and as a unique and mobile performance venue. By using only half of a historic Harvestore silo, the semi-cylindrical structure projects sound outward and the roof of the silo protects performers (and their equipment) from the elements.

Shimon and Lindemann’s work spans many mediums, including photography, painting, music, installation, and film. In their 32-year career as collaborative artists, they have created a body of work that poignantly and playfully reflects the beauty and strangeness of the people and places that make up their home state of Wisconsin.

Iconic blue Harvestore silos were built by the A.O. Smith Co. of Milwaukee, Wisconsin and quickly became a symbol of progressive technology-savvy farm practices after their invention in 1949. Once a ubiquitous sighting on the Wisconsin landscape, Harvestore silos fell into disuse by the 21st century and have been gradually replaced by horizontal bunkers, compressed stacks, and plastic silage bags. Constructed from parts of an actual repurposed silo, Shimon and Lindemann's Harvestore Bandshell  breathes new life into this agricultural artifact by transforming it into a stage for music and dance performances.

Harvestores, County K near Brillion, Wisconsin (1.24.2014) Cyanotype. © J. Shimon & J. Lindemann

The Bandshell at Fermentation Fest

The Harvestore Bandshell will be installed at the 2014 Fermentation Fest—A Live Culture Convergence, a 10-day celebration of food, farming, and live culture in all its forms in and around Reedsburg, Wisconsin on October 4-13, 2014. The centerpiece of Fermentation Fest is the Farm/Art DTour, a 50-mile self-guided drive through the beautiful working lands of Sauk County, Wisconsin. For the DTour, these rolling hills are punctuated with art installations, performances in hay fields, roadside poetry, local food stands, and much more.

Fermentation Fest was created by the Wormfarm Institute, an award-winning non-profit organization with the unique mission of integrating culture and agriculture. Their work is recognized as a national model of rural “creative placemaking”—asset-based community and economic development with arts and culture at its core—and was recently featured in a New York Times article about the recent nationwide rural renaissance. 2014 is the fourth annual Fermentation Fest and is expected to draw over 15,000 visitors (a.k.a. “DTourists”) to Reedsburg and Sauk County.

The Harvestore Bandshell will be used as a stage for Pasture Performances—music and dance events scheduled throughout both weekends of the Fermentation Fest (Oct. 4-13).

Field Notes along the the DTour

Budget and Plan

The funds raised through your support of this Indiegogo campaign will offset the expenses of purchasing Harvestore silo parts and the hardware required to assemble it, constructing a sturdy 24 ft. by 12 ft. timber-framed platform for the bandshell, and the labor costs of erecting the entire structure.

C & E Tanks and Silo of Menominee, Wisconsin has secured twelve blue enameled steel panels (about 4 ft. by 8 ft. each) and the roof from a 20-ft. diameter Harvestore silo. One of the panels displays an American flag, a feature highlighting the Bicentennial. A local Amish craftsman (who wishes to remain anonymous) will mill and assemble the lumber to build the sizeable platform upon which the bandshell will be permanently mounted.

John Shimon and Julie Lindemann approached the Wormfarm Institute with a proposal for the Harvestore Bandshell as an installation for the 2014 Fermentation Fest. The opportunity to collaborate on this project came up suddenly and was not covered in the original project budget. However, the chance to work with these remarkable artists to create a unique performance space that reflects the rural experience and the mission of the Wormfarm Institute could not be passed up. The Harvestore Bandshell is a truly collaborative project that benefits both the community and performing artists by providing a mobile venue for engaging music, dance, and art events.

Get Involved! (Pasture Performances)

After donating to support this project, come see the Harvestore Bandshell yourself at the 2014 Fermentation Fest! Four Pasture Performances (free of charge) are already scheduled for the bandshell with others being announced soon:

  • Saturday, October 4th – The Madison Ballet dances to a mashup of classical Italian dance, George Gershwin favorites, 1960’s rock ‘n’ roll, and “steampunk Dracula.”
  • Sunday, October 5th –Mighty Wheelhouse (Madison, Wisconsin) blends the cosmopolitan sounds of Motown and Austin with the down-home bluegrass of the Appalachian hills.
  • Saturday, October 11th – We Go From Where We Know – experimental open-air improvisation featuring John Shimon (guitars), Brian Pertl (didgeridoos), John Gates (vocals), and Leila Ramagopal (harp).
  • Sunday, October 12th – Holy Sheboygan! Energetic and unique seven-member “garbage folk” band from Appleton, Wisconsin.

Additional Pasture Performances are taking place in other venues on the DTour and Fermentation Fest also features many wonderful classes and events. See the entire schedule and plan your visit here.

The We Go From Where We Know Quartet. Watercolor by John Shimon

Life Beyond Fermentation Fest

The platform for the bandshell will include hardwood skids so that a trailer can tow the entire structure. The 12 ft. width of the platform allows for safe towing so the Harvestore Bandshell can be moved and used by performers in surrounding towns and cities. After Fermentation Fest, the bandshell will have a second life as a mobile stage and functional artwork that can be deployed throughout these rural communities.

The city of Reedsburg, Wisconsin has expressed interest in acquiring and maintaining the Harvestore Bandshell and making it available to other performing artists and arts organizations. Reedsburg annually hosts Fermentation Fest and is fast becoming known as the home of innovative rural cultural initiatives.

More Information:

John Shimon, Julie Lindemann, and The Wisconsin Project

The Harvestore Bandshell is part of a larger ongoing body of work by John Shimon and Julie Lindemann called The Wisconsin Project. Encompassing photography, film, performance, sculpture, and numerous historical postcards, The Wisconsin Project is a creative excavation of Wisconsin’s cultural landscape. Shimon and Lindemann are associate professors of art at Lawrence University in Appleton, Wisconsin. For information about The Wisconsin Project visit wisconsinproject.blogspot.com. Shimon and Lindemann’s work can be seen at www.shimonlindemann.com

Fermentation Fest—A Live Culture Convergence – October 4-12, 2014

A food and farming festival celebrating live culture in all its forms—from dance to yogurt, poetry to sauerkraut. Featuring the Farm/Art D-Tour. www.fermentationfest.com

The Wormfarm Institute

Dedicated to integrating culture and agriculture, the Wormfarm Institute is an evolving laboratory of the arts and ecology and fertile ground for creative work. Planting a seed, cultivating, reaping what you sow—both farmer and artist have these activities in common.

Wormfarm is a 501(c)(3) non-profit organization working to build a sustainable future for agriculture and the arts by fostering vital links between people and the land. Generating, supporting and promoting these links between our creative selves, our work and our place on earth are essential for a thriving community.

www.wormfarminstitute.org

tow the entire structure. The 12 ft. width of the platform allows for safe
towing so the Harvestore Bandshell
can be moved and used by performers in surrounding towns and cities. After
Fermentation Fest, the bandshell will have a second life as a mobile stage and
functional artwork that can be deployed throughout these rural communities.
The
city of Reedsburg, Wisconsin has expressed interest in acquiring and
maintaining the Harvestore Bandshell
and making it available to other performing artists and arts organizations. Reedsburg
annually hosts Fermentation Fest and is fast becoming known as the home of
innovative rural cultural initiatives.
More Information:
John Shimon, Julie Lindemann, and The
Wisconsin Project

The
Harvestore Bandshell is part of a
larger ongoing body of work by John Shimon and Julie Lindemann called The Wisconsin Project. Encompassing
photography, film, performance, sculpture, and numerous historical postcards, The Wisconsin Project is a creative
excavation of Wisconsin’s cultural landscape. Shimon and Lindemann are
associate professors of art at Lawrence University in Appleton, Wisconsin. For
information about The Wisconsin Project
visit wisconsinproject.blogspot.com. Shimon and
Lindemann’s work can be seen at www.shimonlindemann.com
Fermentation Fest—A Live Culture Convergence – October 4-12, 2014
A food and farming
festival celebrating live culture in all its forms—from dance to yogurt, poetry
to sauerkraut. Featuring the Farm/Art D-Tour. www.fermentationfest.com
The Wormfarm Institute
Dedicated
to integrating culture and agriculture, the Wormfarm Institute is an evolving
laboratory of the arts and ecology and fertile ground for creative work.
Planting a seed, cultivating, reaping what you sow—both farmer and artist have
these activities in common.
Wormfarm is a 501(c)(3)
non-profit organization working to build a sustainable future for agriculture
and the arts by fostering vital links between people and the land. Generating,
supporting and promoting these links between our creative selves, our work and
our place on earth are essential for a thriving community.www.wormfarminstitute.org

story:
• Have you ever found yourself living the definition of insanity on a daily basis?

  • Or found it hard to say no to things, people or situations that drain you?
  • Or maybe, you’ve allowed unhealthy relationships to block your blessings?

Well…

So have we. And that’s why we chose to write Whose Shoes Are You Wearing? 12 Steps to Uncovering the Woman You Really Want to Be—to share a message and build a movement for self healing and personal transformation with you. We want you to learn to love all of you!

Since launching our book in May 2014 to a standing-room only crowd (we sold out of books that day!), we’ve seen the impact our message has had on young and old, men and women alike:



In fact…

Although we wrote this book for women, we’ve had so many men (including our Dad!) tell us how it’s helping them. In Whose Shoes, we went all out and chose to share with you our failures, our doubts, our challenges—they’re all there in the book. But so are our triumphs, testimonies, and the tools we used to overcome the hard times we all go through. Because whatever you're going through, we've probably been there and want to help you figure out how to push past the pain so you can wholeheartedly pursue your purpose.

What makes this book really different from anything else out there is that fact that we talk about transformation from a cultural perspective, because culture—whether you’re African, Asian, Hispanic, Caribbean, African American, or just moving from the South to the North—plays a huge role in how you see yourself.

But…



We even created a dance to go with it (watch this) and got our kids in on the act! Because this isn’t about us. It’s about them. And you. And all those who are looking for something different. Something powerful. Something inspiring to help them discover who they really are, what they want, and how to get there. So besides this first book, we're working on a few things to help you do just that!

In the coming months, we will be launching new products, workshops, and videos, and have begun developing Whose Shoes into a book series that we’ll be unveiling soon! And this December, we'll be mailing out our exclusive Whose Shoes "Passion, Purpose and Pumps" Calendar to inspire you every day and keep you on track with your 2015 goals (we'll be printing a limited edition). Take a sneak peek below at the launch of our brand new T-shirt line.

We also have our own calendar that’s filling up fast with new dates and venues for future Whose Shoes talks. And we want you to be part of taking this message into high schools, colleges, churches and organizations dedicated to empowering women and youth to embrace their greatness.

And now…

We need your help to continue bringing this message to the masses. Because it takes resources to really make a difference in the way we’ve been called to do. The great thing is, you’re guaranteed that your funding will help change lives. How do we know? Because our readers have told us:


Thanks a bunch for your support and encouragement of this powerful project which will allow us to make our message accessible to so many more people. Every dollar pledged to help us reach our fundraising goal is another dollar towards helping others discover and walk in the shoes God made just for them!

And…

Even if you’re not in the position to make a donation, you can still contribute by telling all your friends about our campaign. If ten people mention your name when making a donation, you’ll receive the $100 level reward. Because whatever it takes, we want you to be part of this.

Alright…

Enough of all this writing. Check out our awesome video at the top of this page produced by the talented Tameka Harris Live to find out why we need you to build this Whose Shoes Movement! 



Make sure to visit us at www.whoseshoesbook.com to stay posted on what we're up to next, and download your FREE chapters of our life-changing book here. Want to find out more? Have questions? Send us an email! Then follow us on Twitter, YouTube, Facebook and Instagram to keep in touch. We can't wait to have you join us on this amazing journey!

*Note: Due to our current speaking schedule, the Whose Shoes Experience Weekend mentioned in the video will be hosted in Spring 2015. Stay tuned...

story:
Charlie Cunningham  and David Cuatlacuatl are both second year MFA students at the Pennsylvania State University.  As part of their thesis project in the spring of 2015, both artists have agreed to collaborate in order to reshape and re-contextualize (reconsider) the structure of the gallery space.

A Word from the Artists...

Artists often exist as a response to social, cultural, and political concerns through direct or indirect acknowledgment.  The show will present an environment  with an attempt to blur the lines between low and high culture.  For this ambitious project, we rely on your support to be able to follow through with its production.  We have the idea and we welcome you to be part of it. 

To fully take on this artistic endeavor we will need to purchase a sizable amount of materials. With help from your generous donations we will be able to truly materialize our vision.  For each donation we will send you a unique art work that will correspond to your donation amount.  These perks will have a variety of materials and be a invaluable addition to any art collection. 

This undertaking will be a pivotal part of our artistic and collaborative careers. With the help of your donations, we can be freed from our financial limitations and create the expansive, immersive, and ambitious undertaking we have conceived. To truly re-imagine Zoller Gallery and make a visual impact on the community at SOVA we will be putting our carpentry, interior design, and manual labor skills to the test.   
If donating isn't something you can do at this time we completely understand.  We still need your help getting the word out on social media.   We will also need volunteers for construction week starting March 9th.  Please let us know if your interested, Volunteers will also be given perks for their time and help.

We can't thank you all enough for your support and generosity, wish us luck!

DavidCuatlacuatl.com
CharlieCunninghamArt.com

story: I am extremely passionate about art and design education. I am a qualified teacher and have taught in schools in London for over a decade. I am now living in Cape Town and want to do something creative which makes a difference to township schools. As part of my MA in art and design education my dissertation communicated my concern for the fact that self expression doesn't have enough importance in the curriculum. Assessment for learning drives the system and the therapeutic and process aspect of creating is left behind. As an artist I value the process of creating over the product. I believe that play and exploration are the essence of creativity. The Drawing Room is a simple and flexible space which will offer one or two children an intimate and private space which is judgement free. The space is designed to allow children to simply be free to express and explore whatever they like! With detachable sheets of paper there is no preciousness or expectations of producing. With a passion for art therapy I believe that this concept also supports the therapeutic element missing in art and design education which is so very valuable. It is of value to all children but those who exist in township communities could really benefit from this safe space to express their inner world. I have made a prototype from cardboard but it is not robust enough. I want to make 4 Drawing Rooms using 6ml plywood with hinges. The Drawing Room will be easily stored as it folds flat. I also want to build a storage facility for materials inside. I have already experimented with the idea and the children really seemed to take to it. I believe it is a low cost, simple yet powerful tool to enable children to express their inner world.

story:
ESPAÑOL / ENGLISH 

Mi nombre es Caterina Trabucco Avalos (Bir Jiwan Kaur Khalsa), soy Chilena, tengo 36 años y me diagnosticaron ​las siguientes condiciones: el Síndrome Ehlers-Danlos tipo vascular​ (IV); entendiendo que la base para el funcionamiento de un cuerpo humano es la producción de colágeno, a nivel celular yo no produzco los colágenos para que tanto mis órganos, músculos y tejidos funcionen de forma normal. Debido a este síndrome, tengo Disautonomía Severa, Fallo autonómico puro (FAP)​ y Hábitos Marfanoides, que quiere decir que mis arterias son extremadamente delgadas con alto riesgo de que revienten al más mínimo esfuerzo o impacto. Tengo Síndrome ​Ehlers-Danlos ​tipo Hipermóvil​ (III). Esto significa que como característica tengo hiperlaxitud articular lo que me lleva a lesionarme con facilidad y tener dificulta motora, con un dolor extremo y crónico. Y también tengo Neumonitis por hipersensibilidad​, que quiere decir que mis pulmones están inflamados constantemente, y ante cualquier inhalación de sustancia extraña (polvo, moho, etc) la enfermedad se activa (para mayores detalles, revisar sección “Anexo”).Este diagnóstico y los múltiples desafíos que ello implica, generan bajas expectativas de vida y una condición que me debilita a diario. Lo descrito anteriormente constituye una mezcla genética única diagnosticada en el mundo y en mi país no existe la tecnología ni el tratamiento para mi caso. Es por esto que se están estableciendo comunicación y vínculos concretos con centros de investigación médica en Europa para el estudio de mi caso.

A pesar de esto, mi fuerza  y mi fe se renuevan cada día, ya que tengo una maravillosa hija de dos años llamada Aima, quien posiblemente ha heredado estas mismas condiciones genéticas, sumado a una condición alérgica severa múltiple. En este sentido, es que necesitamos viajar con urgencia a Francia, al Hôpital Européen Georges-Pompidou,en París, porque en este centro se pueden realizar los estudios y exámenes adecuados para mi condición y la de Aima. El principal propósito es poder estudiar esta mezcla genética única para que Aima pueda tener una mejor calidad de vida, que le proporcione un normal desarrollo físico, social y emocional. Como consecuencia de esta investigación, ayudar a otras personas que tengan alguna de estas condiciones.

Mi estado hoy:

Cada día mi calidad y expectativas de vida disminuyen ya que tengo alta debilidad articular de la parte superior del cuerpo, sufro de mareos, falta de concentración y derrames internos que me provocan mucho dolor. Problemas motrices que se manifiestan con dificultad para hablar y caminar. Actualmente uso muletas para trasladarme.

En mi condición de salud es un desafío tener una vida normal, trabajar, trasladarme, y realizar actividades tan comunes como salir a la calle (mi sistema inmunológico está débil y estoy propensa a los virus y bacterias) 

Lo que necesito es reunir USD $33.000, para costear la investigación y tratamiento médico en el Hôpital Européen Georges-Pompidou, de París, Francia. Es urgente poder viajar para someterme a estos estudios y poder contar con un tratamiento adecuado para mi hija y para mí. Los médicos en Chile me han desahuciado, indicándome que tengo dos alternativas: viajar para tratarme en Francia, o permanecer internada y postrada en una cama, sin poder evitar la degeneración de mi organismo a partir de estas condiciones.

Para mí es un desafío estar en esta posición, pidiendo ayuda monetaria. Sin embargo, como no puedo trabajar y costear este tratamiento, me atrevo a recurrir a todo aquel de noble corazón que pueda ayudarnos en esta misión.

Por favor, ayúdame a reunir los fondos necesarios para realizar este viaje. Agradezco infinitamente de todo corazón la oportunidad de servir a otros a través de mi causa, pudiendo así ayudar a la ciencia médica a través de mi caso. Como mencione antes el estudio de mi condición permitirá ayudar a otras personas que sufren de este tipo de patologías genéticas.

Bendigo tu ayuda y solidaridad, entregando mi causa a tus manos.

Detalle de gastos de viaje médico

Este dinero se utilizará en los siguientes ítems:

- USD $13.214 ($10.000 euros) Examen para identificar la mezcla genética exacta de las condiciones que tengo.

- USD $925 ($700 euros) Examen para mi hija Aima, para identificar la mezcla genética de las condiciones que tiene mi hija Aima.

- USD $2.860 ($2.168 euros) por mes, por concepto de manutención dado que no tengo familiares ni amigos en Francia, que me den alojamiento y comida. Este dinero es para mi hija y para mí. Total: USD $17.160 ($13.008 euros) por 6 meses.

- USD $1.695 ($1.285 euros) por concepto de pasaje en avión ida y vuelta vuelta Santiago, Chile – Paris, Francia.

TOTAL: 
USD $32.994 = $33.000  (EUROS €24.993)

------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

ENGLISH

Help me finance a trip to treat my unique genetic condition!

My name is Caterina Trabucco Avalos (Bir Jiwan Kaur Khalsa), Chilean, 36  years old and diagnosed with Vascular Ehlers-Danlos Syndrome​ (IV). I lack one of the basic functions of the human body:collagen production at a cellular level, which in turn prevents my organs, muscles and tissues from working normally. Due to this syndrome, I have Severe Dysautonomia, Pure Autonomic Failure (PAF)​ and Marfanoid Habitus, which means that my arteries are extremely thin and highly likely to burst upon minimum stress or impact. I have Hypermobile ​Ehlers-Danlos Syndrome​ (III). This means that my joints are hypermobile and easily injured, presenting difficulty to move and extreme chronic pain. I also have Hypersensitivity Pneumonitis, which means that my lungs are constantly swollen, activating the disease upon breathing any foreign particles (dust, mold, etc.) (For more details please check the Appendix). This diagnosis and the many challenges it poses, creates a low life expectancy and a constantly debilitating condition. The traits explained above make up a uniquely diagnosed genetic mix in the entire world and my country does not possess the technology nor treatment for it. This is why we have estabished communication and ties with European medical research centres interested in my case.

In spite of this, my strength and faith are renewed every day thanks to my beautiful two year-old dautghter named Aima, who may have possibly inherited the same genetic conditions, as well as a multiple severe allergies. This is why we both need to travel urgently to France, to Hôpital Européen Georges-Pompidou in Paris, because they can carry out the proper research and tests for me and Aima. The main purpose is to be able to study this unique genetic mix and ensure a better quality of life for Aima,allowing her to develop physically, socially and emotionally. This research may also help other people with my present conditions.

My situation today:

Every day my quality of life and life expectancy are diminished, since I have very little joint strength in my upper body, suffer from headaches, lack of concentration and internal bleeding that causes tremendous pain, as well as problems walking and speaking. I currently have to use crutches to move.

It is challenging to have a normal life in my condition, to work, move and perform normal activities such as going out on the street (my immune system is weak, making me an easy target for viruses and bacteria).

I need to get USD $33.000, to pay for the cost of the medical research and treatment at Hôpital Européen Georges-Pompidou, in Paris, France. I urgently need to travel and begin testing to get proper treatment for me and my daughter. Doctors in Chile have declared me a lost cause, saying that my only two options areto travel to France for treatment or stay in bed waiting for my body to slowly degenerate.

Asking for money is not easy for me. However, since I cannot work to pay for this treatment, all I can do is to ask for the help of kind-hearted people who are able to take us closer to our goal.

Please, help me gather the necessary funds for this trip. I am truly grateful to have the change to help medical science and others through my case.  As mentioned earlier, the study of my case will help other people like me who suffer from similar congenital pathologies.

I put myself and my cause in your hands, blessing you for your help and solidarity.

Medical Trip Expense Details

The money will be used in the following items:

- USD $13.214 ($10.000 euros) Test to identify the exact genetic mix of my condition.

- USD $925 ($700 euros) Test for my daughter Aima, to identify the exact genetic mix of her condition.

- USD $2.860 ($2.168 euros) per month, to sustain myself since I have no friends or family in France to provide food and shelter. This money is for me and my daughter. Total: USD $17.160 ($13.008 euros) for 6 months.

- USD $1.695 ($1.285 euros) for a return plane ticket between Santiago, Chile – Paris, France.

TOTAL: 
USD $32.994 = $33.000  (EUROS €24.993)



ANEXOS/APPENDIX
ESPAÑOL

En términos médicos, mi condición implica:

1) El Síndrome de Ehlers-Danlos vascular de tipo IV, también conocido como síndrome de Ehlers-Danlos (SED) de tipo vascular, es un trastorno hereditario del tejido conectivo definido por rasgos faciales característicos (acrogeria) en la mayoría de pacientes, piel translúcida con vasos subcutáneos muy visibles en el tronco y en la parte baja de la espalda, moratones fáciles y graves complicaciones arteriales, digestivas y uterinas, que rara vez se observan en las otras formas de SED

2) El Síndrome de Ehlers-Danlos, tipo hipermóvil (Tipo III) (HT-EDS) es la forma más frecuente del EDS, un grupo de enfermedades hereditarias del tejido conectivo, y se  caracteriza por hiperlaxitud articular, hiperextensibilidad cutánea leve, fragilidad tisular y manifestaciones extra-muscoloesqueléticas.

3) Hábitos Marfanoides, que son síntomas del síndrome de Marfan (MFS). Es una enfermedad sistémica del tejido conectivo, caracterizada por una combinación variable de manifestaciones cardiovasculares, músculo-esqueléticas, oftalmológicas y pulmonares.

4) La neuropatía sensorial y autonómica hereditaria tipo 3 (HSAN3, por sus siglas en inglés) es un trastorno hereditario caracterizado por disfunción sensorial y afectación grave de la actividad del sistema nervioso autónomo, dando lugar a una disfunción multisistémica

5) El fallo autonómico puro (FAP) es una enfermedad neurodegenerativa que afecta a la rama simpática del sistema nervioso central autónomo y que se manifiesta con hipotensión ortostática

6) La neumonitis por hipersensibilidad (HP) es una enfermedad pulmonar con síntomas de disnea y tos, que resulta de la inhalación de un antígeno al cual el sujeto se ha sensibilizado previamente 


ENGLISH

In medical terms my condition includes:

1) Type IV Vascular Ehlers-Danlos Syndrome, also known as vascular Ehlers-Danlos Sydrome (EDS), a hereditary disorder of connective tissue defined by very distinct facial features (acrogeria) in most patients, translucent skin with very visible blood vessels in the upper body and lower back, easy bruising and severe arterial, digestive and uterine complications, rarely seen in other forms of EDS.

2) Type III Hypermobile Ehlers-Danlos Syndrome (HT-EDS) is the most frequent form of EDS, a series of hereditary disorders in connective tissues characterized by joint hypermobility, slight skin hyper-stretching, fragile tissues and extra-muscular/skeletal manifestations.

3) Marfanoid Habitus, symptoms of Marfan Syndrome (MFS). A systemic connective tissue disease, characterized by a variable combination of cardiovascular, skeletal-muscular, ophtalmological and lung manifestations.

4) Type 3 Hereditary Sensorial and Autonomic Neuropathy (HSAN3) isa hereditary disease characterized by sensorial dysfunction and severe affectation of the autonomous nervous system, making way for multi-systemic dysfunction.

5) Pure Autonomic Failure (PAF) is a neurodegenerative disease affecting the sympathetic branch of the autonomous central nervous system and which manifests through orthostatic hypotension.

6) Hypersensitivity Pneumonitis (HP) is a lung disease with symptoms of dyspnea and coughing, produced by the inhalation of allergens to which the person has become previously hypersensitive.

Tengo Síndrome ​Ehlers-Danlos ​tipo Hipermóvil​ (III). Esto significa que como característica tengo hiperlaxitud articular lo que me lleva a lesionarme con facilidad y tener dificulta motora, con un dolor extremo y crónico. Y también tengo Neumonitis por hipersensibilidad​, que quiere decir que mis pulmones están inflamados constantemente, y ante cualquier inhalación de sustancia extraña (polvo, moho, etc) la enfermedad se activa (para mayores detalles, revisar sección “Anexo”).Este diagnóstico y los múltiples desafíos que ello implica, generan bajas expectativas de vida y una condición que me debilita a diario. Lo descrito anteriormente constituye una mezcla genética única diagnosticada en el mundo y en mi país no existe la tecnología ni el tratamiento para mi caso. Es por esto que se están estableciendo comunicación y vínculos concretos con centros de investigación médica en Europa para el estudio de mi caso.A pesar de esto, mi fuerza  y mi fe se renuevan cada día, ya que tengo una maravillosa hija de dos años llamada Aima, quien posiblemente ha heredado estas mismas condiciones genéticas, sumado a una condición alérgica severa múltiple. En este sentido, es que necesitamos viajar con urgencia a Francia, al Hôpital Européen Georges-Pompidou,en París, porque en este centro se pueden realizar los estudios y exámenes adecuados para mi condición y la de Aima. El principal propósito es poder estudiar esta mezcla genética única para que Aima pueda tener una mejor calidad de vida, que le proporcione un normal desarrollo físico, social y emocional. Como consecuencia de esta investigación, ayudar a otras personas que tengan alguna de estas condiciones.Mi estado hoy:Cada día mi calidad y expectativas de vida disminuyen ya que tengo alta debilidad articular de la parte superior del cuerpo, sufro de mareos, falta de concentración y derrames internos que me provocan mucho dolor. Problemas motrices que se manifiestan con dificultad para hablar y caminar. Actualmente uso muletas para trasladarme.En mi condición de salud es un desafío tener una vida normal, trabajar, trasladarme, y realizar actividades tan comunes como salir a la calle (mi sistema inmunológico está débil y estoy propensa a los virus y bacterias) Lo que necesito es reunir USD $33.000, para costear la investigación y tratamiento médico en el Hôpital Européen Georges-Pompidou, de París, Francia. Es urgente poder viajar para someterme a estos estudios y poder contar con un tratamiento adecuado para mi hija y para mí. Los médicos en Chile me han desahuciado, indicándome que tengo dos alternativas: viajar para tratarme en Francia, o permanecer internada y postrada en una cama, sin poder evitar la degeneración de mi organismo a partir de estas condiciones.Para mí es un desafío estar en esta posición, pidiendo ayuda monetaria. Sin embargo, como no puedo trabajar y costear este tratamiento, me atrevo a recurrir a todo aquel de noble corazón que pueda ayudarnos en esta misión.Por favor, ayúdame a reunir los fondos necesarios para realizar este viaje. Agradezco infinitamente de todo corazón la oportunidad de servir a otros a través de mi causa, pudiendo así ayudar a la ciencia médica a través de mi caso. Como mencione antes el estudio de mi condición permitirá ayudar a otras personas que sufren de este tipo de patologías genéticas.Bendigo tu ayuda y solidaridad, entregando mi causa a tus manos.Detalle de gastos de viaje médicoEste dinero se utilizará en los siguientes ítems:- USD $13.214 ($10.000 euros) Examen para identificar la mezcla genética exacta de las condiciones que tengo.- USD $925 ($700 euros) Examen para mi hija Aima, para identificar la mezcla genética de las condiciones que tiene mi hija Aima.- USD $2.860 ($2.168 euros) por mes, por concepto de manutención dado que no tengo familiares ni amigos en Francia, que me den alojamiento y comida. Este dinero es para mi hija y para mí. Total: USD $17.160 ($13.008 euros) por 6 meses.- USD $1.695 ($1.285 euros) por concepto de pasaje en avión ida y vuelta vuelta Santiago, Chile – Paris, Francia.TOTAL: USD $32.994 = $33.000  (EUROS €24.993)------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------ENGLISHHelp me finance a trip to treat my
unique genetic condition!
My name is Caterina
Trabucco Avalos (Bir Jiwan Kaur Khalsa), Chilean, 36  years old and diagnosed with Vascular Ehlers-Danlos Syndrome​ (IV). I lack one of the basic
functions of the human body:collagen production at a cellular level, which in
turn prevents my organs, muscles and tissues from working normally. Due to this
syndrome, I have Severe Dysautonomia, Pure Autonomic Failure
(PAF)​ and Marfanoid Habitus, which means that my arteries
are extremely thin and highly likely to burst upon minimum stress or impact. I
have Hypermobile ​Ehlers-Danlos Syndrome​ (III). This means that my
joints are hypermobile and easily injured, presenting difficulty to move and
extreme chronic pain. I also have Hypersensitivity Pneumonitis, which
means that my lungs are constantly swollen, activating the disease upon
breathing any foreign particles (dust, mold, etc.) (For more details please
check the Appendix). This diagnosis and the many challenges it poses, creates
a low life expectancy and a constantly debilitating condition. The traits
explained above make up a uniquely diagnosed genetic mix in the entire world
and my country does not possess the technology nor treatment for it. This
is why we have estabished communication and ties with European medical research
centres interested in my case.
In spite of this, my
strength and faith are renewed every day thanks to my beautiful two year-old dautghter named Aima, who may have possibly inherited the same genetic
conditions, as well as a multiple severe allergies. This is why we both need to travel urgently to France, to Hôpital Européen
Georges-Pompidou in Paris, because they can carry out the proper research
and tests for me and Aima. The main purpose is to be able to study this
unique genetic mix and ensure a better quality of life for Aima,allowing
her to develop physically, socially and emotionally. This research may also
help other people with my present conditions.
My
situation today:
Every day my quality of
life and life expectancy are diminished, since I have very little joint
strength in my upper body, suffer from headaches, lack of concentration and
internal bleeding that causes tremendous pain, as well as problems walking and
speaking. I currently have to use crutches to move.
It is challenging to
have a normal life in my condition, to work, move and perform normal activities
such as going out on the street (my immune system is weak, making me an easy
target for viruses and bacteria).
I need to get USD
$33.000, to pay for the
cost of the medical research and treatment at Hôpital Européen
Georges-Pompidou, in Paris, France. I urgently need to travel and begin testing
to get proper treatment for me and my daughter. Doctors in Chile have
declared me a lost cause, saying that my only two options areto travel to
France for treatment or stay in bed waiting for my body to slowly
degenerate.
Asking for money is not
easy for me. However, since I cannot work to pay for this treatment, all I can
do is to ask for the help of kind-hearted people who are able to take us closer
to our goal.
Please, help me gather
the necessary funds for this trip. I am truly grateful to have the change to
help medical science and others through my case.  As mentioned earlier, the study of my case
will help other people like me who suffer from similar congenital pathologies.
I
put myself and my cause in your hands, blessing you for your help and
solidarity.
Medical
Trip Expense Details
The money will be used
in the following items:
- USD $13.214 ($10.000
euros) Test to identify the exact genetic mix of my condition.
- USD $925 ($700
euros) Test for my daughter Aima, to identify the exact genetic mix of her
condition.
- USD $2.860 ($2.168
euros) per month, to sustain myself since I have no friends or family in France
to provide food and shelter. This money is for me and my daughter. Total: USD
$17.160 ($13.008 euros) for 6 months.
- USD $1.695 ($1.285
euros) for a return plane ticket between Santiago, Chile – Paris, France.
TOTAL: 
USD $32.994 = $33.000  (EUROS €24.993)ANEXOS/APPENDIXESPAÑOLEn términos médicos, mi condición implica:1) El Síndrome de Ehlers-Danlos vascular de tipo IV, también conocido como síndrome de Ehlers-Danlos (SED) de tipo vascular, es un trastorno hereditario del tejido conectivo definido por rasgos faciales característicos (acrogeria) en la mayoría de pacientes, piel translúcida con vasos subcutáneos muy visibles en el tronco y en la parte baja de la espalda, moratones fáciles y graves complicaciones arteriales, digestivas y uterinas, que rara vez se observan en las otras formas de SED2) El Síndrome de Ehlers-Danlos, tipo hipermóvil (Tipo III) (HT-EDS) es la forma más frecuente del EDS, un grupo de enfermedades hereditarias del tejido conectivo, y se  caracteriza por hiperlaxitud articular, hiperextensibilidad cutánea leve, fragilidad tisular y manifestaciones extra-muscoloesqueléticas.3) Hábitos Marfanoides, que son síntomas del síndrome de Marfan (MFS). Es una enfermedad sistémica del tejido conectivo, caracterizada por una combinación variable de manifestaciones cardiovasculares, músculo-esqueléticas, oftalmológicas y pulmonares.4) La neuropatía sensorial y autonómica hereditaria tipo 3 (HSAN3, por sus siglas en inglés) es un trastorno hereditario caracterizado por disfunción sensorial y afectación grave de la actividad del sistema nervioso autónomo, dando lugar a una disfunción multisistémica5) El fallo autonómico puro (FAP) es una enfermedad neurodegenerativa que afecta a la rama simpática del sistema nervioso central autónomo y que se manifiesta con hipotensión ortostática6) La neumonitis por hipersensibilidad (HP) es una enfermedad pulmonar con síntomas de disnea y tos, que resulta de la inhalación de un antígeno al cual el sujeto se ha sensibilizado previamente 
ENGLISH
In
medical terms my condition includes:
1) Type
IV Vascular Ehlers-Danlos Syndrome, also known as vascular Ehlers-Danlos Sydrome
(EDS), a hereditary disorder of connective tissue defined by very distinct
facial features (acrogeria) in most patients, translucent skin with very
visible blood vessels in the upper body and lower back, easy bruising and
severe arterial, digestive and uterine complications, rarely seen in other
forms of EDS.
2) Type
III Hypermobile Ehlers-Danlos Syndrome (HT-EDS) is the most frequent
form of EDS, a series of hereditary disorders in connective tissues
characterized by joint hypermobility, slight skin hyper-stretching, fragile
tissues and extra-muscular/skeletal manifestations.
3) Marfanoid
Habitus, symptoms
of Marfan Syndrome (MFS). A
systemic connective tissue disease, characterized
by a variable combination of cardiovascular, skeletal-muscular, ophtalmological
and lung manifestations.
4) Type
3 Hereditary Sensorial and Autonomic Neuropathy (HSAN3)
isa
hereditary disease characterized by sensorial dysfunction and severe
affectation of the autonomous nervous system, making way for multi-systemic
dysfunction.
5) Pure
Autonomic Failure (PAF) is a neurodegenerative disease affecting the sympathetic
branch of the autonomous central nervous system and which manifests through
orthostatic hypotension.
6) Hypersensitivity
Pneumonitis (HP) is
a lung disease with symptoms of dyspnea and coughing, produced by the
inhalation of allergens to which the person has become previously hypersensitive.

story:
Short Summary

My name is Ofer Grunwald, and over the past few years, I've dedicated my life to the study and practice of bonsai - a form of scultpure with living trees.

Having had the opportunity to study with one of the great European bonsai masters of our time, I've set myself a goal of spreading the word, and promoting this amazing art in my home country of Israel.

To this end, and in collaboration with the Jerusalem Botanical Gardens non-profit organization, I've set up the Jerusalem Botanical Gardens Bonsai Award and Exhibition. The Bonsai Award and Exhibition is a unique opportunity that gathers the best works from artists all over Israel, and allows them to showcase their trees. The event includes demonstrations by leading international artists, who award a cash prize to the best trees in the show. This year, we're looking forward to hosting international bonsai masters Enrico Savini from Italy, and Tony Tickle from the UK.

The Bonsai Awards and Exhibition is a one-of-a-kind event, which promotes excellence among local artists, and offers them a chance not only to showcase their trees to the general public, but to receive international recognition through the visiting judges and the general interest the event generates abroad.

For me, this is truly a labor of love, and I am delighted to invite you to be a part of this initiative and have a real and lasting impact on shaping a fledgling artform in my country!

What We Need & What You Get

Following on the success of last year's first-ever event, this year we're looking to have an even greater reach, both internationally and locally.

We're looking to raise $4000 to bring another international headliner, who can generate a lot of interest among bonsai artists abroad, offer more and better prizes for the winners, and offer more admissions and tours, so that more people will be able to experience the best bonsai that Israel has to offer.

The Jerusalem Botanical Gardens have pledged to match every dollar you donate, so every donation goes even further! They've also donated some additional perks which I am happy to be able to offer to you.

If you live overseas, but have friends or family in Israel, we'll be more than happy to gift the VIP admission and the one-year membership to them, so that they can enjoy the event made possible with your help.

Every dollar counts, and will help make the 2012 Jerusalem Botanical Gardens Bonsai Award and Exhibition even more successful and meaningful for the local artists.

story:
I was a career U.S. Army NCO who deployed in 2003-2004 for Operation Iraqi Freedom.

I was the Section Chief of the Combat Service Support Automation Management Office (CSSAMO), and supervised a great, hard-working highly motivated group of young soldiers.

Four months after my return, my situation took a turn and gave me some new challenges. I lost all the sight in my right eye and, some 18 months later, I lost most of the sight in my left eye. The sight I have in my left is 20/700 with no central or peripheral vision as compared to a normal field of vision.

During my Blind Rehabilitation Training at two VA Centers they use wood working to improve your manual skills. I discovered the joy of wood working.

I find it inspiring to have learned that it is possible to mentally capture an idea, and with patience and learned skills, have that idea take shape as a handmade item.

So with patience I see the images in my mind and mentally figure out how to possibly capture them in wood.

I take pleasure in making my entry: to capture not only my ideas and dreams but possibly, to inspire those who hear my story; and to other challenged Veterans that need the inspiration to dream and take the challenge to accomplish their dreams.

The area I now am using as my shop is overcrowded and is becoming unsafe.

I want to continue working of the new skills that I have been shown.

The funds raised will allow for me to move my shop for its present location, my garage to a larger and safe dedicated area for my wood work.

As stated above I hope that my accomplishments in wood working after losing my sight can help motivate others to overcome their challenges

story:
About

My name is Dominik Tezyk, and I am a 3D artist from Bonn, Germany. I have worked now for many years on a 3D recreation of the Titanic, the most famous sunken ocean liner of all time. I have worked on my model now for a very long time and have put endless amounts of time and effort into this project. I have been interested in the Titanic ever since I was a child. 

You might ask yourself; what differs my 3D work from the other 3D Models of the famous vessel? Well, it's simply the grade of detail. I am building the most detailed model of the ship to date, and I am modeling it to be as historically accurate as possible.

I'm planning to later release a picture book about my model with information such as how it was constructed, etc, and it will also be filled with beautiful renders and never-before-seen images. It will be a sort-of "Ken Marschall"-esque book, but with my own images, renders, posters, and other interesting behind-the-scene peeks.

Prior to this summer I had hardware that was suitable for this project. Then, while I was on vacation, someone broke into my apartment and stole all my hardware. As a result, all my data, work, and working tools are gone. To continue with my project I will need a new workstation and working tools.

How does my work look so far? I have quite a few followers on my facebook 3D Project site (https://www.facebook.com/groups/293322404129215/), you can see much more of my work there. 


What I Need & What You Get


  • I will need about 4200 Euros. This will go into software (Autodesk Maya), a computer (16-32 core i7, 64 GB RAM, Graphics card, mainboard, case), a PC 27" screen, hard drives, and a cloud based database solution.
  • With this equipment I will recreate the ship, like never before!!!
  • If the 4200 Euro goal is not fulfilled, I will still find a way to raise the rest of the money.


    Timeframe

    This project will take a long time to complete; about 2 years, but the contributors are still guaranteed to get some very interesting goodies once the project is completed.

    Other Ways You Can Help

    If you can't contribute with donations, but you still want to help, you can still share this project and campaign on any social media platform such as Facebook, Twitter, Instagram and others.
