story:
About Myself

My name is Jordan Chaney and I am a Poet/Teacher/Public speaker, residing in eastern Washington in the United States. I work in Juvenile Justice Center and in Alternative schools teaching poetry and communications skills. I also perfrom in lead workshops around the greater northwest helping people find their confidence and their voice. 

Opportunity: Attending a Workshop at the Athens School of Fine Arts in Athens, Greece

I am starting this campaign because I just recieved a letter of acceptance for a 2 week performance workshop from the Athens School of Fine Arts in Athens, Greece. This workshop will be held by La Pocha Nostra, a world renown performance troupe. They only select 22 participants from around the globe and they chose yours truly to be one of the participants.

Attending this workshop is important to me because it will help keep me sharp in my craft and all that I am taught and inspired by will reach the thousands of people that I have been given the amazing opportunity to reach!

By helping me out you are helping out the youth and the communities that I am involved with as well. I speak and perform at Elementary Schools all the way up to the College level and even for Charities and Wineries too. I have a wide and diverese audience that I am able to reach and I want to continue to give them my very best!  

What We Need & What You Get

I need to raise $2,500 quick, fast and in a hurry as the deadline is approaching in just a few short weeks!

The Tuition is $950.00 US and the plane ticket is fluctuating around $1,500.00 US.

Other accomodations are taken care of.

What's in it for you??

If you donate $25.00 you will recieve a free signed copy of my new book Rocket Fuel for Dreamers!

and

If you donate $100.00 dollars or more you will get the signed copy of my book Rocket Fuel for Dreamers AND my good friend who is a Wine Afficionado, Andy Perdue, is going to give you a fine bottle of wine!! 

I am an independent artist and I have come a long way in my artwork. I have not done it alone. It has been by the love and support of all the people I have met along the way. Anything that you are able to help with will be greatly appreciated!! 

If you are unable to donate but want to help please share this with your friends and family!! Thank you so much!! -Jordan

story:
We are seeking $10,000 in funding necessary for architectural plans, blueprints, legal assistance, and other prerequisites to complete a final plan for approval by Jacksonville's City Council. This is the first step towards the completion of an 82,000 sq. ft. visual and performing arts venue. A center that will provide:

• Arts education for citizens in the area
• Jobs and gallery opportunities for local artists
• Performing arts programs for local children and adults
• Hosting of ongoing visual and performing arts shows
• Rental of studio space and a performance venue for local artists and groups

The Armory is a city-owned building that is located at 851 North Market St., on the corner of Market and State Street. The Armory was built in 1914 and has been used for a variety of functions. During its heyday it featured such performers as Duke Ellington, Ray Charles, Janis Joplin, and The Allman Brothers. The Jacksonville Parks and Recreation Department most recently called it home, but vacated the building in 2010. Since that time this once spectacular building has fallen into disrepair with mold, holes in the roof, and other signs of decay. The ARTery will transform this once popular destination into an arts center that features art studios; a gallery; dance, music, art and drama classrooms/studios; and a 500-seat theater.

We deeply appreciate all of the supporters who cast their vote for The ARTery (#20145) at One Spark. We came in #4 in the art category and #12 overall with 998 votes, but more resources are needed to move The ARTery forward. 

Our community needs a thriving downtown art hub. The Art League, Art Center Cooperative, and The Performers Academy are dedicated to transforming this historic building into a central location for artists, performers, and musicians to collaborate, showcase, learn, and perform for citizens of all ages. With your support we will make The ARTery a reality! All donations are fully tax deductible,
story_txt:
We are seeking
$10,000 in funding necessary for
architectural plans, blueprints, legal assistance, and other prerequisites to complete a final plan for approval by Jacksonville's City Council. This is the first step towards
the completion of an 82,000 sq. ft. visual and performing arts venue. A center that will provide: • Arts education for citizens in the area• Jobs and gallery opportunities for local artists• Performing arts programs for local children and adults• Hosting of ongoing visual and performing arts shows• Rental of studio space and a performance venue for local artists and groupsThe Armory is a city-owned building that is located at 851
North Market St., on the corner of Market and State Street. The
Armory was built in 1914 and has been used for a variety of functions. During its heyday it featured such performers as Duke
Ellington, Ray Charles, Janis Joplin, and The Allman Brothers. The Jacksonville Parks and Recreation Department most recently called it home, but vacated the building in 2010. Since that time this once spectacular building has fallen into disrepair with mold, holes in the roof, and other signs of decay. The ARTery will

story:
Statement of Purpose: The Exhibition and Our Goals

Our project, Uninhabited Rooms, is about self-sacrifice and sharing. It’s a creative process about setting aside our individual pursuits to discover and promote new ways of working and experience the collective power in art.

The initial 2017 exhibition that took place in El Barrio´s Artspace PS109, featured painting, photography, sculpture, video and sound. It was the outcome of a three-year endeavor and a long-standing friendship.

This multifaceted and experimental project has come out of our need to connect and expand through creativity and dialogue. Because of this, we want Uninhabited Rooms to be an international traveling show, including workshops and further exchange with other artists in the United States as well as in countries such as Italy, Mexico and The Netherlands.

Involving the Nature, Discourse and Practice of Collaboration in Art

Given the degree of human strife in our globalized world, we believe that art plays an ever more vital role in opening discourse among people. One of our main goals is to explore the artistic possibilities of collaboration as a means of personal and community awareness. Informed by cultural diversities, we seek to offer a creative antithesis and give relevance to this difficult time in the world, which is marked by issues that divide rather than connect us.

Our Project’s History

After meeting on a regular basis to wine, dine, and discuss our personal accomplishments and professional goals, we had an epiphany. One night, during one of our gatherings, Barbara read a poem she had written, inspired by a dream, that came as a message from a friend who had died.

The crux of the poem says:

look within

 

move into your life

the uninhabited rooms

pain and sorrow are just trickster

who have move in while you were away

starve them and return home

The poem and its reference to uncharted space was a point of departure for discourse and experimentation. The stream of thoughts and interpretations that were discussed that evening, sparked our need to enter new visual territory. The premise was based on the idea of giving up something for a greater purpose, the idea of sacrifice that would confront us with unforeseen change and ultimately a form of transmutation.

Our Intention

By modifying each other’s work, we stepped out of our comfort zone to enter a realm of absolute uncertainty; moving from one form into another with abandon and trust. We pushed our boundaries in favor of a larger picture by exploring different formats and questioning the aesthetic of collective practices.

We relinquished individual authorship by altering and transforming each piece, resulting in a three-person collaboration. Working with, but not limited to painting, photography, video and sound, our intention is that our exploratory journey act as a channel to connect with others.

The Artists

Maura Falfán, Antonia Guerrero and Barbara Schaefer have solid backgrounds and years of experience working as professional artists.

Antonia works with multiple media for her installation pieces combining drawings, lighting, video, performance and sound. She draws upon her Mexican and American backgrounds to explore themes of bicultural identities and ongoing cultural hybrids.

Maura has developed a body of work centered in the idea of the vestige. Interested in the possibility of transformation and personal catharsis, she has welcomed an ominous quality in her work and promoted a sense of mystery through the use of a monochromatic palette.

After extensive years living in Rome, with its poetic sense of time, Barbara’s current interest lies in its fatal intersections where history is hidden. She seeks to reveal those invisible aspects, which are secretly encapsulated everywhere, including within ourselves.

Maura Falfán completed her MFA at Pratt Institute, Brooklyn, NY (2008-2010) and her BFA at the National School for Painting, Sculpture and Etching (ENPEG) La Esmeralda, Mexico City (1996-2001). She was recently selected for the XVII Rufino Tamayo Painting Biennale, Museo Rufino Tamayo, Mexico City and participated in this year´s Whitney Biennial, under Debtfair, a project of Occupy Museums, Whitney Museum of American Art, New York, NY.

Maura has had numerous exhibitions both nationally and internationally in museum and gallery settings. She has been the recipient of important grants in her hometown and participated in relevant venues such as MACO; SCOPE; Museo Carrilllo Gil; Museo Universitario del Chopo, and Museo de Arte Moderno, Mexico City. In 2013 she formed part of the New York Foundation for the Arts (NYFA), ArtePreneur Professional Development Program, New York, NY.

http://www.maurafalfan.com

Antonia Guerrero’s work has been exhibited in Mexico, the United States, Puerto Rico, France, Germany, Spain, Romania, including venues such as the Museum of Modern Art Mexico, the Palacio de Bellas Artes, the Diego Rivera Museum and Mexico City Museum, Mexico. In New York City:  MediaNoche Gallery, Taller Boricua, Latin American Gallery New York, NoMaa Gallery, A.I.R Gallery and the Snite Museum, Notre Dame University, Indiana.

Among Antonia’s awards are the US-Mex Bi-Cultural Rockefeller Foundation Grant for her Performance Malintzin, the Valparaiso Foundation Artist Residency, Spain, the Pollock Krasner Foundation Grant, Cuts and Burns Media Residency, Penn State University Foreign Scholar Residency. She has also received awards from the Artist Fellowship, Change, Inc. and the Mayer Foundation.

Antonia’s professional activities include theater, contemporary dance, and performance art, and as a soloist with the dance-theater Company Purpura in Mexico City. She studied at Trinity University, San Antonio, Texas 1965/66, the San Carlos Art Academy UNAM 1967/68, Mexico and at Pratt Institute 1968/69, New York.

http://www.antonia-guerrero.com

Barbara Schaefer is an interdisciplinary artist whose paintings and photographs are exhibited internationally. She obtained a BFA and from The University of Arizona and an MFA from San Francisco State University. She won a Helen Wurlitzer Foundation Artist-in-Residency award in 1997, the New York Foundation for The Arts Sponsorship in 1996, a grant from the Robert Rauschenberg Foundation in 2004 and an Artist-in-Residency award at the Fundación Valparaiso in 2005.

In 2011, Barbara had a solo museum exhibition at the Museo Comunale D’Arte Moderna in Senigallia, Italy and received a grant from Franklin Furnace. In 2015, Barbara’s photography was exhibited at the Louvre Museum in Paris, France and at the Scope Art Fair in Miami. In 2016 she had a solo exhibition in Rome, Italy at Studio Matacotta.

Barbara's many years of living in Rome, Italy had a significant impact and influence on her work and in her life. The city's beauty inspired her toward refinement and aesthetic choice, while its omnipresent history, such as the facades of old Rome, weathered with patina, permeated her work. Italian culture and language, so rich and lively, compelled her to think and act in ways she would not have otherwise discovered.

https://www.barbaraschaefer.me 

http://barbaraschaeferart.com

 

About our first exhibition space: El Barrio´s Artspace PS109

El Barrio´s Artspace PS109 is a live/work space for artists located in East Harlem. Antonia and Maura are both residents of this former school and are happy to be part of a new and thriving community of multinational artists and creative professionals. We chose to have the first exhibit here because of its immediate accessibility and communal nature.

http://www.artspace.org/about

Engaging the Community (After all, this is about collectivity and inclusion)

Our long-term goal for Uninhabited Rooms is to establish an inclusive itinerant exhibition project, which will include a long and continuing community engagement program consisting of:

•          Workshops

•          Open discussions

•          Collaborating with other artists

•          And community-based creative projects

Our initial experience at El Barrio´s Artspace PS109 provided a short-lived and concise experience that has, nevertheless, enabled us to foresee the positive outcome and benefits that can stem from a structured and guided public outreach program.

Our next step is to find another venue in New York and present a revamped version of Uninhabited Rooms along with specific workshops and mentorships focused on youth and supported by like-minded community groups.

What we need to reach our Goal

Our expenses have exceeded our savings accounts’ liquidity, and here’s where we need your help.

The initial amount needed to get our itinerary project going is $7,500.

This would cover:

  •      The materials required for the completion of the exhibited artwork
  •      Installation equipment, including: projectors, plasma screens, sound system, and more.
  •      Expenses for transporting artwork to future exhibition spaces
  •      Promotional material
  •      And every other behind-the-scenes expense that comes with coordinating an exhibition.
  •      Payment to our awesome and talented assistant, Ana Sepulveda, who worked tirelessly without pay to help us with our first   exhibition at  El Barrio's Artspace in September. Her contribution was invaluable!

Thank you for your attention and interest.

Like a pebble tossed in water creating far reaching ripple effects, we hope to share and expand this creative field of partnership with you!

We are very grateful for your support!

Antonia, Barbara and Maura

story:
First, to everyone who rallied around the launch of Vol. 1 last year, THANK YOU! Because of your support we have since donated over 2,000 books and seen our community grow so purposefully! We could not have done it without you.

Our Mission

ColorATL exists for the community of Atlanta to intimately connect with local art while experiencing the benefits of creative activity. For years members of the ColorATL team have connected local artists with people in health facilities and marginalized communities throughout the city, constantly observing how the creative process decreases stress, anxiety, and despair - and cultivates peace, joy, hope and connection. 

Volume 2

Our second edition of the Atlanta Coloring Book welcomes 40+ Atlanta-based artists into the ColorATL family. Each have created a unique page for you to get to know and color. Through ColorATL, you will not only relax, create and connect to the diverse art culture of Atlanta, but for every coloring book purchased, ColorATL delivers a free copy to a person at our local, partner organizations (list below).

2017 Artists

Alex Laney - Andrew Catanese - Angie Jerez - Austin Blue - Blake Borowski - Brooke Powell - Catlanta - Charmaine Minniefield - Christine Nishiyama - Daniel Byrd - Dustin Cramer - Erin Palovick - Fabian Williams - Fahamu Pecou - Foxyswine - HENSE - David Fratu - Janice Rago - JEL - Jeremy Brown - Joe Dreher - Josh LaFayette - Katherine Stockton - Katlin Shae - Killamari - Lindsay Ryden - Manty Dey - Maxwell Sebastian - Monica Alexander - Niki Zarrabi - Noosh - Rachel Eleanor - Sara Lehtman - Sarah Emerson - Scott Silvey - Shanequa Gay - Stenvik Mostrom - Tiffany Charesse - Tiny Doors ATL - Tori Tinsley - Travis Smith - Willis Norman  

The Book 

The design team at ColorATL is adamant in delivering the highest-caliber publication, including:

  • Short bio and a personal statement from each artist alongside their artwork
  • Highest quality printing
  • Scuff-proof, Matte cover
  • Heavy-weight, 70# Soporset opaque paper
  • Lay-flat binding, so it’s not a pain to color near that pesky, center crease
  • 9 x 12 inches for more room to color and larger artwork to hang after completion!

1 : 1 Receiving Organizations

The Dream Center, The Gateway Center, Emory Winship Cancer Institute, RemergeATL, ChopArt, PaintLove, Mercy Care, Peachford Hospital, Piedmont Hospital, Scottish Rite, AGRhodes Health and Rehab, Formation Counseling, Summit Counseling, Children's Miracle Network, Egelston, Kid in All of Us, YouthSpark, and more!

Our Community Partners: Atlanta Contemporary, CreativeMorningsATL, Emory Winship Cancer Institute, RemergeATL, General Assembly, PaintLove, The Giving Kitchen, ChooseATL, RedBull

Campaign Details

The aim of our pre-sale campaign is to help cover printing and design costs, totaling approximately $11,000, which will deliver 5,000 books (2,500 for sale, and 2,500 gifted).  All excess funds from this campaign will go to support therapeutic art programs in local health facilities and social impact organizations throughout the city of Atlanta.

Lastly, we welcome you to join us at our...

Vol. 2 Launch Exhibit!

Oct. 25th from 6-10pm at:
Monday Night Garage - 933 Lee St SW, Atlanta, GA 30310

Please reach out and contact us with any inquiries: ATLcoloringbook@gmail.com

Thank You!

 

FYI: That awesome video above was produced by the amazing Katie Hawkins! Thanks Katie!

story:
I have launched this campaign to help me fund attending a painting workshop with Autumn Skye Morrison.  She is an amazing visionary art painter and is offering a workshop "Soul Portraits" in January. Here is the link below:

https://www.facebook.com/events/677977165623198/

For the past 14 years I have been raising my daughter and I have worked as a bodyworker full time all of those years, so have not had tons of free time!!!. 3 years ago I kept having visions of myself painting so I picked up a brush and have been in love ever since.  It is one of things I love to do most in life!! I never knew until 3 years ago how much I loved making art.   I now finally have time to pursue my painting now that my child is older and is much more self-sufficient!!!! It is so exciting to have so much creative energy waiting to be expressed!!!

I have been teaching myself to paint and mostly experimenting!! I feel like this workshop would help me so much to gain some technical skills.  Autumn Skye Morrison is an amazing visionary artist and will be teaching specifically portrait painting this workshop.  Painting portraits is one of my favorite things to paint and in a visionary art style. This is the PERFECT workshop for my tastes in art!!!!

The funding will help to pay for the workshop and my plane ticket there.  If I do not raise the total goal to  make it to the workshop, I will try to come up with the rest myself. If I do no get close to goal, I will use all of the money on art classes here in town.  There are no visionary art classes in the town that I live in so to be able to make it to this one would be a dream come true!!!

I have many different perks ranging from prints to original paintings at sale prices!!!

You can check out all of my art on my Facebook and Etsy shop: ArtbyPyara

Thanks for all of your support!!!!!

story:
Short Summary

Hi, my name is Nikolay, and I'm a happy father of my daughter, Maria.

I believe that she is a good painter, and she want to present her pictures in a book.

We want to create the first Maria's book with own illustrations, please help us with this.

It's very important for us, and not only because of money. First of all we want to receive good feedback, so even your "thanks" is a big deal for us.

What We Need & What You Get

You should know how you're helping by donating:

  • We need to raise US$1000. It's not a lot, we do need it only for papers and other materials required for the book.
  • Everybody who helps us to get closer to our goal will get super rewards and different symbols of appreciation, all from the bottom of our hearts. What about a picture for your every birthday? Check out all the perks you can get with your donation!

The Impact

Maybe because of you this world will receive new talented painter, who knows?

Risks & Challenges

We don't see any risks here since we already have a lot of paintings and ready to introduce them to everybody.

Other Ways You Can Help

We know that some people just can't contribute, and that's ok. But that doesn't mean you can't help.

Get the word out! There is a super big chance you may know someone who can donate!
Use IndieGoGo sharing tools, or post a link to this campaign on your social media!

Thank you so so much for taking the time to learn about our project.

I believe that she is a good painter, and she want to present her pictures in a book.
We want to create the first Maria's book with own illustrations, please help us with this.
It's very important for us, and not only because of money. First of all we want to receive good feedback, so even your "thanks" is a big deal for us.

What We Need & What You Get
You should know how you're helping by donating:

We need to raise US$1000. It's not a lot, we do need it only for papers and other materials required for the book.
Everybody who helps us to get closer to our goal will get super rewards and different symbols of appreciation, all from the bottom of our hearts. What about a picture for your every birthday? Check out all the perks you can get with your donation!


The Impact
Maybe because of you this world will receive new talented painter, who knows?

Risks & Challenges
We don't see any risks here since we already have a lot of paintings and ready to introduce them to everybody.

Other Ways You Can Help
We know that some people just can't contribute, and that's ok. But that doesn't mean you can't help.
Get the word out! There is a super big chance you may know someone who can donate!Use IndieGoGo sharing tools, or post a link to this campaign on your social media!
Thank you so so much for taking the time to learn about our project.

story:
Brownie In Motion is a traveling art installation, photographic darkroom, and functioning camera obscura modeled after an iconic Kodak Brownie. Each donation to this campaign helps bring the camera obscura across the United States and supports an important portrait project that turns the camera lens on artisans and craftspeople whose niche skills are on the verge of disappearing.

Your contributions to this campaign go specifically towards the purchase of new lighting gear, photographic chemicals, film, fuel and any remaining direct positive paper we can get our hands on! The images produced through Brownie In Motion will result in a public art exhibition and possibly a book! Please consider donating to Brownie In Motion, so that the camera obscura can one day visit your town!





What We Need & What You Get

We need to raise $10,000 to buy equipment, photographic supplies (film & paper) and pay for travel expenses (gas, tolls, food, lodging) while photographing artisans across the American west with the camera obscura. We are continually refining our onsite development system and need cash to build a cart that can double both as an equipment dolly and a darkroom sink. We also need to update some of our lighting equipment to help us expose images in the camera obscura when lighting conditions are less than ideal.

In particular, we are hoping to purchase the following pieces of lighting gear:

4800 w/s power pack and heads x 2
C-Stands with extension arms x 2
Travel Battery & Case
Disk Reflector

By donating to Brownie in Motion, you not only get the peace of mind that comes with supporting a historically significant photographic project but you can also get some pretty cool rewards, like limited edition prints, postcards, a private workshop or the chance to have the world's largest Brownie camera appear at your event as a photo-booth!


The Impact

Through the photographic process, we hope to preserve pieces of our cultural history and perhaps generate an interest in crafts at the risk of being lost. Through public outreach events, Brownie In Motion helps facilitate dialogue about art, science, craft and making.


Other Ways You Can Help

  • You can help us to get the word out and make some noise about our campaign.
  • We are gladly accepting in-kind donations of photographic chemistry and equipment
  • Please remember to use the Indiegogo share tools!

story:
Help Me Get Weird! *make art

www.vimeo.com/grantcox -see more of my creations here!

www.sculpturespace.org -artist-in-residence program I will be attending! Oct.-Nov.

http://box13artspace.com -location of my exhibition! Mar. 8th - Apr. 12th 2014

Throughout my career as an artist, I have come to think of myself as a janky roboticist, building machines that are the opposite calling of one who would roboticize. The conventional idea is that machines are productive and efficient in order to take the place of a human. Pairing grandiose with pathetic, my focus is challenging this notion by making the machines closer to what I see as humans: anxious, quirky, idiosyncratic, and often unproductive. Based on the operation of my current creative practice, I use my sense of humor to turn my thoughts of everyday happenings into a comedic performance about these human characteristics.

Now I have a chance at developing this concept with two great opportunities that will require traveling and building expenses.  First will be an artist residency at Sculpture Space in Utica, NY.  There, I will be provided with a place to live and a facility capable of building anything my imagination can conjure. Building materials will not be provided. To help with such things, the residency offers a two thousand dollar stipend. Out of that stipend, the organization charges a nominal fee for out-of-state recipients for the room they will be occupying during their stay. Sculpture Space strongly suggested securing outside funding.  Once I make these creations I need to transport them to a gallery in Houston, TX; this is the “phase two” of my funding campaign.  During March of 2014, my work is scheduled to be exhibited at Box 13 Art Space, which is a nonprofit facility with a focus on the advancement of experimental contemporary art. I plan to transport the work in a box truck and drive down to Houston and install what will be an exciting first solo exhibition outside of academia. 

I am asking for your support by donating toward the costly shipping methods, truck rentals, fuel costs, and building supplies including but not limited to wood, steel, hardware, and other devices that help give life to my work. If you contribute, the capacity of what I create will only expand, the work can be more humorous, and your contribution could allow not only the work to go more places, but enable the artist to evolve to a new level. You would be doing an absolutely positive act of kindness and what you will see at Box 13 Art Space will be a physical representation of your generosity.

My goal is five thousand dollars. The funds will lighten the constraints on materials, allowing me to build without worry and allow me to be creative as I possibly can be. Whether it buys a sheet of plywood or a sandwich, any contribution will significantly help! Also, at the end of my time in residence, I will have to arrange for the work to be transported and stored until mid-February when I will be transporting the installation to Houston, TX and again when the exhibition closes in April. The only numbers I want to deal with while building are measurements, not wondering the about the cost of materials and food. A fellow artist that I have supported said that “dreams are expensive,” and with this road in front of me, I would have to agree. I am calling on you to give what you can and most importantly, believe in me. Thank you!

Sincerely,

C. Grant Cox III

Here are some things that got weird from the past:

      Night Fever. 2013. Wood, Nails, Bathroom Rug, Underwear, Socks, Cement. 97”h x 14”d x 25”w.

        Internal Dialogue. 2011. Snare Drum, Cymbal, Tripod, Microcontroller, Servomotor, Inner tube, Wood. 36”h x 18”d x 14”w.

         The End.  2010. Coconut Shell, Microcontroller, Servomotor, Clamp, Coffee Cans, Hose Clamp, Light, Tripod, Wood. 18”h x 14”d x 14”w.

     Totally Hot!.  2010. Bicycle, Treadmill, Garage Door Motor, Contact Microphone, Playing Card, Speakers, Fan, Wood Crate. 84”h x 72”d x 36”w.

story:
My name is Chloe Barcelou and I'm a 23 year old conceptual and fine art photographer, set designer, stylist and clothing fabricator. I have been interested in photography since I was about 17 and have been producing my own conceptual photo shoots for the past six years. Often working with limited resources, I hand-make props and costumes as well as furniture and backdrops. From start to finish I conceptualize, produce, coordinate, manage, style and photograph my images- sometimes even modeling for them. Please take a moment to look at my website at www.ChloeBarcelou.com to gain a better visual understanding of what I do. 

This campaign is important to me because it helps to locally raise awareness for my art and creations- often leading to jobs and connections that might have otherwise been missed. As this would be my first exhibit, I would be very excited and pleased to professionally show my art, hard work and dedication in a beautiful gallery space. 

But I need your help! I need to raise $500 by September 9th to cover the upfront cost of high quality archival prints and matting services. 

From start to finish, my photo-shoots are funded out of my pocket or by the contributing kindness of family and friends. Although I have learned to utilize my resources cleverly, they are still incredibly time consuming and very expensive. Your contribution would be valuable to me because this is simply something I cannot fund alone. In doing so, you're helping the dreams of a young and pursuant artist achieve her goals.

Please check out the perks I have outlined below. If my campaign is not fully funded, I will still put whatever funds I am able to raise towards high quality prints and matting services. 

If you are not able to monetarily contribute, please raise awareness for this campaign by sharing it with your friends VIA Facebook, Tumblr, Email or other social media outlets. 

You can find me at the links below.

Thank you so much! <3

story:
Hello! We are working to bring murals to the children and youth of The Children and Youth Empowerment Centre (CYEC) in Nyeri, Kenya. The CYEC is a residential and educational program supporting over 150 street dwelling and vulnerable youth and children ages 3-22. Here is a link to their website: http://www.cyec.net/

The CYEC has wonderful programs but their facilities completely lack colors and pictures. There is no art to stimulate the young minds that reside there and there isn't enough funding to allow for the children and youth to create art. Because of this, I have created The CYEC Kenya Mural Project: Bringing Art to Disadvantaged Youth in Kenya. It is an initiative designed to integrate art into the surroundings of the CYEC. We plan to create four murals on walls of the Centre. 

These murals will be created through the collaborative efforts of the CYEC’s youth artists and the other youth and children living at the CYEC. The artists, youth and children will work together to decorate their new home. This includes working together to determine the mural themes and to paint each mural.

For many of the children at the CYEC, this will be their first opportunity to paint. To prepare for the project, the youth artists will teach the youth and children how to paint. They will work one-on-one to teach basic artistic techniques. The youth and children will practice their new skills by helping the artists paint each mural. 

Teaching the children and youth to paint will not only brighten their home, but may also brighten their future. In Kenya, one piece of art can make the artists a lot of money. Tourists pay top dollar for handmade art. One of the youth's paintings featured in the video sold for nearly a quater of the average Kenyan's yearly salary.  

The murals will create a colorful and stimulating learning and living environment as well as a lasting legacy, but not without your help! We need $1500 in order to complete the project. Please help us reach our goal!

Your help is greatly appreciated!

story:
‘Thingamajig’ is an exhibition comprising a series of kinetic sculptures dealing with the phenomena of fragmented identity. The aim of the project is to draw attention to the direction our modern society is heading, through the use of art and humor, unveiling abstract situations that we face daily in our need for belonging. 

 

 

Why Thingamajig is important

 

I believe the current developments in the political and social climate call for a counterbalance movement. The Thingamajig project aims to engage the audience in facing the complex challenges of today's global culture through multidisciplinary art.

 

By combining technical means of interaction and conceptual means of cultural exchange in my kinetic sculptures, I create a playground that stimulates communication. The audience is triggered to reflect on subjects such as nationalism, integration, migration, multiple identities; the idea of the self in relation to the social environment.

 

So far, I have and need

 

At the moment the project has been granted partial funding by the AFK (Amsterdam Fund for the Arts), for which I am eternally grateful, and this enables me to create two of the five kinetic installations initially designed; 'Land escape' and 'Thank god for not making me a man'. I believe this limits the impact of the exhibition, however, and seek additional funding to create the remaining three sculptures ('Twenty one times', 'Going to earth' and 'Sweet home') and present them in different venues in order to reach a much wider audience. For the time being, an exhibition will be held in Retort Art Space and in Planet Art, although with some extra funding I could extend this to other venues.

 

In order to achieve this, I require an additional $ 6100 to cover the necessary materials for the art works.  This includes fiberglass, mechanical and electronic components, engines, cables, silicon, wood, metal and a couple of screws.

 

If you cannot support me financially

 

I still love you.

 

You could support the project on facebook and help me spread the word.

Maybe you know of people or institutions that would be interested in (supporting) the project.

Maybe you have or know of an interesting venue which I could use to extend my exhibitions.

If you are anywhere near the venues, please drop by and share in the Thingamajig experience.
